job_title: Clinic Business Representative Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Regular hours, decent benefits, interesting work. If you're looking for 40 hours a week, and regular start/stop times, you can find them at an Allina Clinic. Allina has a good benefits package and many other benefits that aren't insurance related. You get thorough and ongoing training. Allina really cares about their patients and you're part of something special.
cons:
One of my biggest problems with Allina's PTO policy is that to get paid for a holiday that would land on a regular working day, you have to use YOUR PTO. If you want to take 5 days off, but you only have enough PTO to cover 4 days, too bad. You can't take 5 days. 
We unfortunately had some bullies at the clinic I worked for, and that made it really tough. I wish there would've been an easier way to deal with it.

review_title: Allina doesn't care about their employees
job_title: Patient Care Coordinator in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: Decent health insurance for a single person that has a low deductible.
cons:
Allina has decided to decrease PTO accrual for employees that have been employed with them for over a certain amount of years. 
If you are anything besides an RN, do not expect ANYTHING over a 3% raise, if they'll even give you that (employees that have worked here for 20 plus years dont even get 3%).
They no longer will allow you to roll over any end of year PTO after a certain number. 
They only match 2% of your 401k. 
Do not expect any bonuses or employee appreciation incentives besides a pizza party or a plant.
The turnover rate is unreal which leaves you to do 3 peoples jobs and continue to stay under appreciated.
AGAIN, if you are anything but an RN, do NOT expect any sort of advancement opportunities specifically in the business office aspect of Allina. You're a scheduler? Well, guess what? You'll always be a scheduler.

pros: You get to work with people and try to help them as best as you can
cons: The training is a month (5 weeks) but you are partner with people that really don’t care so they train you how ever way they want. Some are really good at training. The employees will definitely tell you how much they hate the job or management but they are only there for the money. If you work overnights you’ll definitely see nurses sleeping on the floor sometimes even in front of the cameras. But my favorite is how management will pick and choice. review_title: The Most Dysfunctional Place I've Ever Worked as a HR Professional
job_title: Human Resources in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
There are some amazing clinical staff who truly care about patients.
There are good people working in this organization who want to do the right thing. If you decide to go work there, seek them out, because your relationships with them will be the only thing that keeps you sane.
Some positions are allowed to work remotely during and post the COVID pandemic.
cons:
HR leadership is terrible and lacks the self-reflection to realized how terrible they are. I've never seen anything like it. They can't hire effectively externally into HR positions because of the terrible reputation they have in the marketplace, and, if they do, the new hire is typically gone within the first year. You truly can't appreciate how bad it is until you work there. If you are a HR person and you care about your happiness and your career, you'd be better off staying unemployed than accepting a job there. It's so bad that I left without another job because I couldn't handle working there for one more day.
The organization is hypocritical. They tout a 'commitment to care', but they couldn't demonstrate less care to the people who work there. I've never felt less heard or valued then I did during the time I worked there.
Most of the clinical organization is unionized, and that culture has carried over into non-union roles. That means you can work there forever with no expectation that you are performing. And if you are non-performing, you'll never get that feedback because they don't care about you as a person; rather, they'll eliminate your job but not tell you the real reason. 

Working in healthcare is hard under the best circumstances, and Allina Health is a worst case scenario. Unionized, weak leadership, financially struggling, COVID, etc. Do not join this company thinking that you are going to change things...it is broken beyond repair. I have never been so happy to leave a job, and my mental health has improved 100% not being there.

review_title: Allina is the best company I've worked for in my 25+ years of IT Systems Engineering and Management experience.
job_title: Corporate Office IT Staff Member in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
1. Allina's senior leaders and almost all of the employees care deeply about our patient care, our place as a member of the communities we serve and the employees at our healthcare facilities and in the corporate office.

2. Allina treats everyone fairly and with compassion.

3. The Allina corporate offices have a very open and engaging environment. Allina corporate office staff, from the most junior new-hire to the most senior Allina executive have full, true open-door access to each other. This provides a very engaging work environment, and yet never feels "big brother-ish".
cons:
Allina's salaries and annual increases are lower than the national averages for similar job classes and employee experience.

Allina's employee healthcare is weaker, more limited in coverage, has fewer in-network providers, and is significantly more expensive for employee out-of-pocket costs than at all previous companies for which I've worked. However, I don't know whether this a reflection of the current overall trend of employee healthcare nationwide (as of February, 2013), or a true weakness of Allina specifically.

pros: Allina has many locations, you can travel across the company.  If your family has to move for one reason or another, there is likey another Allina facility near.
cons:
Allina Hospitals and Clinics has a huge problems with communication.  Many things are "kept secret" from employees in the planning phases.  This discourages employees when changes are made without input from those it directly effects.  Ineffective changes are made, time is wasted spending time fixing things in the retroactive phase of a project vs being proactive. 

Secondly, Allina, in general, including HR is not dedicated or supportive to its current employees.  Current employees can apply for a position within their current facitily and the applications are not even sent to this facility...shouldn't lateral transfers within a facility take presendence (or at least be considered!)?  

Many Allina facilities are currently encouraging "float" positions vs stationary positions within departments.  This creates less confidence in ones job and you move about.  It also discourages the ability to build teams and work together.

pros: They have great benefits, and most work well with you if you are going to school. They help pay for part of your schooling as well if it is related to healthcare. I've switched departments and have had two very good managers that were great at listening to my concerns and I could tell genuinely care about me. I work in a smaller hospital in southern Minnesota and the president of the hospital makes a point to learn every single employees name at the hospital which is about 300-400 people. They treat their employees to BBQs and Christmas parties. They have a seniority system so people who have been with Allina longer have priority over which hours they would like to work or open positions over external employees which can sort of be a con if you are a new hire. If you refer someone to work for Allina then they give you a $300 bonus. Their training is pretty good and if you have to drive to the cities for training they give you the IRS compensation for gas which is I think 54¢ a mile.
cons: Their Christmas bonus is sort of a cheap gift where the employees that been there longer said they used to have really good bonuses/ gifts. Other employees can sometimes cause drama for you or they get upset because of the seniority system in place.

job_title: Systems Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: No pros for working with this company. Health insurance is terrible
cons: Salary ranges are all over the board. If you get promoted within the company your salary stays lower.

review_title: Several business and IS managers are too political, petty and divisive.
job_title: Information Technology in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The teams and non-management personnel throughout Allina are dedicated to doing their best work to provide great healthcare and increase  patient safety, from the frontline healthcare providers to the backend business analysts, HR, application and IS technical personnel. Most individuals with any seniority keep their focus on our true reason for being: excellent and compassionate patient care.
cons: Salaries start at the low end of good, and increases are lower and slower than several other regional healthcare systems. Nurses have had three strikes in less than ten years to keep management honest, fair and transparent. The fact that nurses have felt the need to strike Allina more frequently than at any other regional health system in the previous decade due to unfair negotiations, and poor public and staff relationships is worthy of serious consideration, regardless of your personal opinion about organized labor.

review_title: Management and Human Resources Fail Employees
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Edina, MN
pros: Hours, Co-workers, pay, locations, schedulers
cons: Management and HR only care about money and not employees

job_title: Registered Respiratory Therapist in Buffalo, MN
pros: Good benefits, great company, good hours
cons: No cons, great place of employment

job_title: Manager in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Pretty good pay and benefits
cons: Long hours and a lot of hard work

job_title: Patient Access Navigator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: My co-workers are awesome! I love working with some of my co-workers, they are the nicest people ever. You accumulated PTO faster than most places that I had worked in the past. The benefit is pretty nice as long as you stay in-network. I believe in Allina's mission and love the way it gearing toward in the future.
cons:
The attendance policy: if your one minute late, you'll get half a point. If you get 4 full points, you will be fired.
I hated that we need pto for everything. You have to used pto for sick day, holiday, being late to work, just about everything.
I have to question how some people become supervisors or manager, especially if they have never been trained in that department. In my department, my supervisor is pretty bad; our day is determine by her mood. If she is happy, work is fine that day. If she is mad for whatever reason, our day will be bad. 
Management need more training in my department. 
Also, there is ways to much favoritism in my department that it causes problem with the employees.

review_title: Good benefits and pay but terrible schisms between departments.
job_title: Call Center Representative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Some of the best benefits I’ve ever gotten. Great starting pay even for entry level.
cons: The management style was punitive and a waste of resources: paper, people’s attention (away from helping customers), and especially a waste of time because the calls were all recorded. There were incentives to being a better nicer employee to patients - but not enough self care and concern for us as human beings to continually call on the reserve of empathy so integral to helping people who are sick or in danger. There was massive burn out, and long term employees acting as wedges stuck in management positions preventing “lower” employees from focusing on what’s really important.

job_title: Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Very easy to do job wise
cons: No cons As of right now

job_title: Registered Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Helping others is my main goal
cons: They are not ethically sound

job_title: Administrative in Minneapolis, MN
pros: best place ever, will continue to work
cons: no cons, pretty cool place

job_title: Medical Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Feeling part of a Community.
cons: Employees not being held accountable for their actions

job_title: CMA (AAMA) in Champlin, MN
pros: Competitive pay wages for the area
cons: Poor management, high Urgent Care turnover.

job_title: in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Ok pay, ok benefits, should have paid holidays but don't for most non- union workers.  Union workers have much better conditions and pay here and better support when management issues.  Managers have much better situation.  Conditions might be awesome here under good manager but opposite under other.
cons: Poor that company excludes holidays and makes they come from PTO.  Management receives better PTO and won't ever let staff take a day off.  If you ask and they say no and you have to take it, even for family need/doctor etc they warn you could be written up/even fired.  Limped because they denied time to go to doctor and knew I couldn't take it without approval.  Manager said no and then I told her I cancelled it and she said really, are you sure.  If she could allow me to go, why wouldn't she just do that?    They didn't successfully reward good workers enough to make you want to stay on and deal with the bad workers who hurt department.  Disengaged tenured workers bringing system down.

review_title: Great place to work for if you're independently wealthy.
job_title: Technical Support Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The employees make it worth coming in day to day.
cons: The pay and benefits are awful. We have the highest health care employee costs.The best annual review rating will only earn you 3 percent raise. With the cost of living what it is I don't know how much longer I will be able to continue to work at Allina. Sr. Management really needs to be overhauled. Every year the engagement reports faults Sr. Management and nothing ever gets done about it.

review_title: I was looking for a chance to grow, but the "fertilizer" was overpowering.
job_title: Supervisor in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Patients receive great patient care.  Allina provides top quality care for patients from all walks of life and 98% of the direct care givers that I worked with would do anything they could for each and every patient, as well as the families of those patients.
cons: Senior management verbalizes the transparency of the company while hiding tons of garbage behind lead lined concrete walls.  If not for the dedication of the real, caring "average" employee, patient care would be in the toilet.  The  most difficult mine field to traverse is the political one.  The truth is often buried, and if an employee is brave enough to expose it, the resulting explosion can be very damaging.  Thus, many good ideas are not shared for fear of stepping on a mine.

review_title: Great place to work, particularly in BHS units.
job_title: Behavioral Health Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Wonderful benefits package; really great coworkers; more support for innovative ideas and listening to complaints we had, as staff.  Most of all, the management really implemented safety measures to keep patients and staff safe on the job, reducing injuries across the board.  Uninsured individuals given no different treatment.  Overall, good place to work.
cons: There are obviously problems with select staff members, but it seemed like management was willing to listen to this, most of the time.  One big problem in BHS is that the group therapy staff kept getting fewer hours, or they didn't hire new staff, and this was a problem for the nursing staff, because we had to put out many more fires that likely wouldn't have been issues if patients had been less bored and more engaged in therapeutic activities.

review_title: GREAT Location, CEO Needs to Go
job_title: Data Analyst, Intermediate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I love where I work and I love the work that I do. I love my job. It's great and the people I work directly with are fantadtic as well. HR's Recruitment Center does a really good job screening candidates! Plus, the corporate office is right next to the Midtown Global Market, a bank, DMV and has a heated tunnel to walk in to your car in the winter.
cons: Constant layoffs occur. HR for staff issues is really bad and not supportive. Disability requests go ignored, are denied, or not approved. Complaints about extremely inappropriate temp employees go ignored. HR temporarily hires more temps than employees so that they don't have to pay out benefits. The CEO asks for your feedback, and then reprimands you for saying anything that he doesn't agree with. Out financial goals are not being met because he's always yelling at someone rather than doing his job.

job_title: Insurance Billing Specialist in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Mission of the organization headed by Connie Wheeler is impressive. Accruing PTO based on the hours worked is nice as is the newly remodeled cafeteria. Nice facility with good lunch options and the greenway walking path. Lots of ways to volunteer and meet people outside your department. Lots of nice people work here.
cons: The workload for BCBS as a payor is unmanageable. Productivity is tracked but with so many remote workers people who under perform are not accountable. Employees with 5-10 experience do not have to perform at a higher level than new hires. 9 claims per hour so if you can bang it out you can milk the system. Non-management employees are not as important and your work is taken for granted. Case in point, department Christmas party never happened as it usually does, was talked about once or twice, and then no one dared ask about what happened.

job_title: Systems Office Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The company is financially stable and has benefited from capable leadership over the past decade. The salary and benefit packages are competitive in many (but not all) areas.
cons:
Everyone in the System Office (The Commons) works in a cubicle, which makes sustained concentration and confidential conversations almost impossible.

Although one of the company's values is integrity, some in leadership roles do not model it with any degree of consistency, and those over them turn a blind eye to specific instances of these lapses.

Human Resources is very inconsistent across the various hospitals and clinics. HR in the System Office, in particular, focuses on trivialities and ignores huge problems. Their advice is unhelpful and unrealistic.

job_title: Finance in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Great marketing, branding, and PR departments; they do a great job hiding how the company is rotting from the top down. 
Good health benefits.
cons: Everything besides the pros above. I've worked at this company for more than ten years in various departments. It has gone from a wonderful place to work to a place in which literally everyone who has the skills to find employment elsewhere has done or is doing so. That means that the people left at Allina are so useless than no other company would hire them. The place is rife with gossip, favoritism, drama, stress, anger, and disillusionment. Horrible compensation. No work-life balance.

review_title: A good company overall, but lots of red-tape and far too protocolized
job_title: Staff Pharmacist in Saint Paul, MN
pros: This is a financially strong company and most jobs are very stable.  Good retirement benefits (especially if you stay a long time), good health care insurance and generally good collaboration amongst the different departments
cons: There are far too many protocols and rules to follow.  Managers really don't think outside of the box and usually they want you to simply "follow the protocol" as opposed to actually think for yourself.  Getting new initiatives approved takes a ton of unnecessary work - it's nearly an act of Congress to get simple things changed.  Also, if one hospital does something, all the hospitals have to do it the same way, even though patient populations vary quite a bit between locations.  The protocol based system is really not always the best in healthcare.

job_title: Clinic Licensed Practical Nurse in Saint Paul, MN
pros: The company's mission of taking care of the whole people and encouragement of community service is positive. Everyone is very welcoming, I was impressed when I first started.  Good insurance, medium pay.
cons: They hire managers to run the clinics that have no experience or have personal agendas and put them in charge of 2 or more clinics so employees dont have daily support and resources.  The upper management has no idea what dysfunction and ineffective work flows exist.  The president's goals for quality patient care does not match many of the clinics practices.  Making money for the department trumps choosing procedures that would allow better long term outcomes for patients.  Little chance for advancement.

job_title: IS Business Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I work with very good people. We are allowed to work from home 1 day a week. The benefits are good. $300.00 deductible per person per year. $10.00 copays (Allina First Plan).
cons:
PTO for holidays, sick time, and vacation is combined, holidays are not paid, you take vacation time for all holidays and all sick time. 

Allina eliminated their pension program. This went away a few years ago. In times of an unsteady economy, a pension is important.

No incentive programs for employee morale or rewards for doing a good job. They have $25.00 drawings for gift cards but extremely rare.

Hard to receive a promotion or move up in your position unless you move to a different job altogether. Very stagnant growth opportunities. They are always cutting back on spending and combining jobs/managers to eliminate costs.  

Need more flexibility in work/life balance.

review_title: Is it a great hospital (it is) or is it a money-making facility for only the top 1% of employees!
job_title: Medical Coder in Minneapolis, MN
pros: well-respected hospital in the community.  Abbott Northwestern is a great heart hospital and most doctors are great.  Unfortunately, they have to spend too much of their time pleasing management.  The bosses are the ones who control everything and of course, make the money.
cons: Too corporate with big salaries going to the CEOs, not the medical professionals and periphery.  money is way too important here when negotiating and communicating with employees.  they even give out "report cards" as to how "we" are doing.  as if the average employee cares or can influence most financial outcomes for the hospital.  they are kidding themselves if they think we think this stuff is important to us personally.

review_title: Amazing providers, hindered by the corporate umbrella that is Allina.
job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Richfield, MN
pros: Some of the most brilliant, kind and dedicated physicians I have ever worked with. MDs that have been in their field for longer than I have been alive.
cons: Consistently irrelevant micromanaging by supervisors including "learning moments" that consist of literally 3 upper management personnel that meet with you separately to find out why the wrong rapid strep was ordered,  or why you were not able to respond to a patient via my chart within 2 hours (with the chaos of clinic, being generally under staffed and the work.lpad of 4 people, it was counterproductive going through the song and dance, when I could be just working instead)

job_title: Mental Health Associate in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Really flexible schedule with a lot of time off.  The staff at Abbott North Western were amazing and overall extremely professional.
cons: As one would expect this job could be extremely stressful and at times dangerous.  Their were a select handful of staff that caused more  behavioral issues than they prevented.  It was no secret who they were, but there was rarely any disciplinary actions taken to discourage them.  The lack of a union for Mental Health associates also created many inequities between MHA's and the rest of the staff on the floors.

review_title: A place to learn, grow, advance......
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Saint Paul, MN
pros: helpful co-workers, great pay/benefits, for the most part, awesome leadership, plenty of opportunites to advance....overall, I had a great experience with this company!!
cons: training is not the greatest, due largely to the fact that Allina provides a number of different medical devices and equipment and keeping up with them and the different criteria/documents required for insurance coverage can be taxing.

review_title: Trust, Respect, Compassion, but not for their employees
job_title: in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Salary and direct compensation are in the ballpark of being competitive for the market. We have a fancy waterfall in our lobby waiting area.  Our CEO is well paid.  United Hospital new President looks pretty and says lots of things that sound good (and that will be as far as it goes, too).
cons: Benefits are HORRENDOUS.  Hospital management is HORRENDOUS.  Coordination between departments is horrible. Staff is rude to each other, due to massive under staffing.  Communication from hospital leadership is completely untrustworthy and incomplete.  The lack of communication and purposeful division of the workers by pitting them against each other within our department by my director is reprehensible.  Department management is totally and embarrassingly incompetent, doesn't understand the jobs they are supposed to be managing, and won't even consider feedback from staff.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
My manager communicated to me that they were receiving praise of my work from others outside our immediate department
Great benefits, especially for a part time position
Many available hours
Competitive pay
Excellent learning environment for nursing students in employee roles
cons:
Little schedule flexibility; difficult to find others in your job class who could and will swap in scheduling problems
Scheduling difficult to coordinate with BSN requirements, despite management promises of accomodation

review_title: If they want you gone, they will find a reason.
job_title: RN Staff Nurse in North St Paul, MN
pros: Clean, good pay, great staff, Central location
cons: Human resources was able to find information or create information put it together inform that was enough to terminate me. I made one mistake and was fired. And you know what that mistake was... I put 15 minutes extra on my time card accidentally and was fired for it. Allina's human resource department sees all staff is expendable. You can be easily replaced. And don't think the union will protect you cuz they had no power whatsoever. I'm trying to condense the story down but it's very interesting and I learned a lot about human resources should be named something else because well the kind of argument resources hiring and firing but with firing someone for one mistake without any discipline or education or opportunity for a second chance.

review_title: Great Company, In the right department.
job_title: Patient Access Liaison in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Awesome coworkers, good benefits, decent pay, no experience necessary to get your foot in the door in many departments. Easy to get in if you know someone.
cons: Constant schedule changes, high turnover, little training, outdated/broken equipment, difficult to transfer between departments due to training differences. Little opportunities for growth. Some employees were "grandfathered" in when Allina merged with other hospitals and do a lot less work, for a lot more pay with in the same department and their jobs are safe while the rest of us are worried about being layed off.

job_title: CMA in Coon Rapids, MN
pros: They have really great training, it's a lot but when you're finally done you feel very confident starting in your position. Good pay and flexible schedules.
cons: Their computer system (Excellian) is kind of all over the place and there seems to be no order in inbasket as far as who is assigned to which doctor. They like to micro-manage which gets a little frustrating. Also even though their training is great, when you're on location training for your position you don't always train on the team you'll be working with so you learn with a different provider which makes things harder when starting on your team.

review_title: Great place to gain experience, but lacks growth opportunities
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Excellent work life balance. Reasonable commute, especially if you can take the bus.  They offer a subsidized bus pass.  Security is available for escort to parking areas.  nice co-workers.  Strong leadership.  Benefits for the most part are better than what I see at other companies.
cons: Pay is competitive with other healthcare non-profits, however you can expect to make about 10% less than profit sector.  Annual employee increases do not meet annual cost of living increases & no opportunity for extra incentive.  Opportunities for career development or advancement are limited, managers typically won't look at a high performer and adapt skills to a new area, they want experience in that exact role.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Maple Grove, MN
pros: Wonderful caring staff.  Willing to do extra to help the clients and each other.
cons: management asks that you use your professional judgment to perform the responsibilities of the job.  the reprimand you when they don't like the decision you make.  Micro manage staff.  preform work metrics on positions that can not be measured by metrics.  expect work to be done in a time frame too short to give quality patient care,  puts patients at risk with budget constraints and policies.

review_title: Likely the best option among metro-area healthcare employers
job_title: Medical Social Worker (MSW) in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great work team, varied and interesting patient population, good support from management, variety of locations/work sites available, benefits are generally on par with other hospitals/clinics,  Management generally seems to be competent, and morale in my department and work area is good.  People are treated fairly, and there are regular and visible employee recogniton efforts.
cons: The same disadvantages involved with any corporate medical setting, basically....senior leadership is sometimes more preoccupied with image than substantive improvements in patient care...and you work with the same vast disparities that you'd see anywhere in the American health care system, particularly at the Abbott-Northwestern campus.

review_title: Health costs go up, salary raises do not
job_title: Information Services Technical Support Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The Health Industry is always growing and jobs are usually in demand, tho at times there are financial cutbacks, and there have been layoffs.
cons: In many areas there is a shortage of employees due to cutbacks causing those that are there to work more hours than they should, causing stressful situations. Mgrs seem to think more about their bonuses than the employees in their departments.

review_title: Has it highs and lows.  Unfortunately the Home Oxygen division seems to be trying to find direction with limited leaders
job_title: DME Technician in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Working with community.  Helping people.
cons: Feeling there is no support of those who will do the work and giving a pass to those who do the bare minimum and do nothing extra.  Members of leadership seem to have no idea of the mission.  Changes are made that negatively impact patient service with no explanation or good reason.  Little chance of advancement.

job_title: Recruitment in Saint Paul, MN
pros: There are so many wonderful things that Allina is involved with and it was so exciting to be a part of one of the best health care organizations not only in the state, but in the country.
cons: The compensation is lacking a lot. They pay way below market value and if you are an internal employee accepting a different job, they pay you the minimum on the pay scale. They are losing great people and great skills over compensating their employees fairly.

job_title: HRIS Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great pay & benefits; ergonomic desks and campaigns promoting employee health
cons: Lack of workplace flexibility; lack of work/life balance; employees are not encouraged to be innovative or speak up; toxic work environment (surrounded by negativity and complaints about those we were supposed to be helping and management); lack of structure and feedback; no structured training plan, disorganized (management hired me without knowing what I'd be working on); working environment needs work, many rows of cubicles with factory-like florescent lights and cement pillars.

job_title: Crisis Clinician in Fridley, MN
pros: I love working in crisis. Management is attentive and reasonable in my experience. Hospital setting is fast-paced and variable, exciting.
cons: Lots of changes in policy and standard work. In the 2 years I have been in this position the assessment structure and standard work are drastically different, and there is always something new that you need to be learning or remembering to do. Working nights is tough, but necessary as there are many on the team with a lot of seniority and experience. Workplace can be dangerous due to the population that we work with in the ED.

job_title: Pro Fee Medical Coding Specialist III in Minneapolis, MN
pros: flexibility with work schedule and PTO when requested.
cons: Limited ability to elevate within the department. Advancement is based on friendship or like/dislike of an employee. One Manager requested that specifically chosen employees apply for open Coding positions. This should have been email to ALL employees, this was not received well from those who have applied in the past. Promotion due to friendship or like/dislike only causes a decline in morale and respect for Management.

review_title: Corporate-feel environment for being a non-profit
job_title: Registered Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Good salary, lots of opportunity for extra shifts and OT, excellent and proficient coworkers.  High level of union support.  Prestigious Magnet facility.  Regular management engagement via staff meetings and email.
cons: Patient care areas need updating.  Workspace and break room space shortages.  Some building security concerns in this very large urban/inner-city hospital setting.  Very low level of managerial support for nursing from the organization — education department is worthless, no direction regarding career advancement.  Increasingly profit driven.  Labor-management issues since the 6 week nursing strike.

job_title: Recruiter in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Love their mission on mind, body, soul, and community.  I believe they take that to heart.  New Management is trying to improve overall business process and how we operate
cons: Not really a con, but it will take  a lot dedication and hard work to get there, exciting times at Allina,  I love change and being a part of the implementations of new programs and processes.

review_title: Great organization with strong focus on the organizational mission.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
Great people with a passion for excellence. Clear direction to provide optimal patient experiences and outcomes.

Flexibility in working from home. Overall, strong management.
cons: Little opportunity for advancement. More work than humanly possible to complete. For non-clinical areas it is sometimes difficult to link the work to the mission. Little recognition for the work of non-clinical staff.

review_title: Good with promoting employees from within, poor on office culture management and benefits administration
job_title: Registered Nurse in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I really like the wide variety of insurance coverage options to choose from and I feel like they do reward good work by promoting internal employees regularly. The overall company qide culture is open and positive but not individual clinic locations.
cons: Larger corporations can get confusing and benefits administration can take a while. You can feel insignificant sometimes.

review_title: Allina - a great place to start a career
job_title: Business Services Educator in Minneapolis, MN
pros: I work on a great team and we all get along really well.  Our director is intelligent and fair and keeps us informed of new things going on at Allina.  I think the communication in our department is excellent.  I feel Allina offers good benefits and promotes a life/work balance.
cons: It depends what location or department you work in.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Minneapolis, MN
pros: The corporate office is lovely.
cons:
How many executives and directors does one organization need? The approval process of having 10 people review something they don't understand gets in the way of progress (have you seen the half-baked website?).  

I would have loved to work at Allina longer; most of my colleagues were wonderful and committed (the others got away with online shopping most of the day because there is no accountability), but the ever-changing moods and opinions of "leaders" dictate the direction and changes monthly.

job_title: in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Great co-workers, nice facilities, benefits.
cons: Leadership's focus is on the almighty dollar.  As much as the lower level managers want to make it seem like "we are putting the patient's needs first" that's not true.  The message is that the admission rate needs to be higher in the hospitals and the discharge rate needs to occur faster.  Yeah... "not for profit" Allina Health.  Don't think so.  They expect you to work until your work is done, and work a bunch of OT for free, rather than hire the staff it takes to reach the goals they're asking you to reach.

job_title: Office Staff in Saint Paul, MN
pros: Slightly competitive pay, mostly friendly co-workers/other departments, easy to request time off without be guilt-over about it, flexible with work schedule (everybody in the same department don't need to have the same work shift, 8am-4:30pm)
cons:
Employee recognition and appreciation of hard work is an e-spot (an e-mailed award certificate), we're not kids trying for the "Hard Worker" award, we're trying to make a living in this bad economy; hard work and dedication should be rewarded with more appropriate incentive like a year-end bonus/cash or gift cards .

Expensive health coverage, no separate funeral/sick/vacation time, no holiday pay (it comes out of your PTO).

Senior management slow to improve/change processes and procedures; nothing is really written down so everyone can follow and do the work consistently and efficiently; overall nothing is organized or structured. 

Management doesn't know or understand all of their staff's work and can't jump in to assist when needed.

Supervisor not professional and play favoritism with certain employees. These employees' work are not monitored so they can Facebook, shop online, or just chat/laugh/instant message all day while the few of us work ourselves tired, even skipping our breaks on some days to get our work done. 

Company encourages career advancement since such a large company but moving within company doesn't seem to happen even though you're qualify or even over qualify for some positions.

Nobody wants to take responsibility, customer phone calls are routed all over and eventually gets send to you (not even the correct department) and by then the customer is frustrated and you unfortunately are on the receiving end of all anger; we have too many departments. Many departments can be combined (i.e. Customer Service and Intake) so that the customer doesn't need to be transferred from department to department just to get a few simple questions answered.

Some departments/branch offices are quite hostile and not professional, e-mails are incomplete, not clear and sometimes out right rude. It's hard to work for a company when the departments can't even work productively together and responsibilities keep being pushed around to some other department. Employees need to be held accountable for their actions.

Management should be aware of employee workload: additional duties shouldn't be added on to an already busy daily schedule and everything still expected to be completed in a timely business standard. One person can't do a 4-person job within an 8hrs shift, no matter how fast they work. Additional support needs to be consistently there (hire another full-time employee) to help and not just rely on other staff when they have time.

Annual reviews are pointless: they make you fill out this entire form about strengths, weakness, and opportunities to improve to supposedly discuss with you for your one-on-one with your supervisor. My supervisor barely looked at mine, I felt rushed into the meeting, she briefly mentioned a few things here and there and had me sign my form and then we were done. What was the point of me wasting my time on the form, so that it'll look pretty in my file.

job_title: in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Allina celebrates diversity and treats all employees equally. I never received any sort of discrimination. Good health insurance, generally wonderful colleagues.
cons: Allina has changed management over the past five years and has changed from an employee/patient focus to a profit-based focus. They have laid people off and transferred the workload of 2-3 people onto 1 person in order to cut costs and increase profit. This leads to unhappy employees who stop caring about their work which in turn affects patient care.

review_title: Best job I have had in 20 years
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Owatonna, MN
pros:
respect, good pay, unique work environment, friendly staff, competent management. 
 I left a good paying job at another large medical facility in southern mn (you know who) after 10 years of being micromanaged and treated like cattle. Allina has been a dream job since day one. A night and day difference. To go to work and actually feel like an adult again, how nice!
cons: health insurance is a bit expensive

job_title: Senior Data Analyst in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Large company with many locations in Minnesota and Western Wisconsin.  If you don't like what you are doing, it is easy to move internally.  Senior leadership is committed to providing the best care to patients despite financial challenges of most healthcare organizations.
cons:
I have maxed out  in my job category.  Other internal jobs that are of interest to me are at a lower pay scale.  I will likely have to leave the company to move forward in my career.   

Unions have too much control at the expense of patients.

job_title: Scheduling in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
The biggest reason I'm still here is because they highly support my education. I'm in nursing school, and they've been so flexible with my school schedule and supportive. Staying with Allina will hopefully make it easier to get a job once I've finished my nursing degree.
I have a great supervisor and great team to work with - we all care about the same things.
As a whole - Allina as a company has beliefs and ideals that I believe in as well. Many patients I work with are satisfied with their care as well and that's huge. 
Allina believes in recognizing people who do good work - who exceed expectations - and getting recognition and awards is highly appreciated. 
The pay is good for what I do, although annual raises are low (1-2%).
If you need benefits - they are very good. Health insurance is affordable, they offer the beFIT credits to lower your premium by living a healthy lifestyle.
cons:
Sick leave and family leave is very difficult. They use "occurrences" and you can only get three in six months. So if I can't make it because my child is sick and daycare won't let him come in, that's one occurrence. Leaving early, coming in late is half an occurrence. It's really hard to keep it within only three in six months when it's the winter months and you and your family are sick or there are snow storms. It's hard when you have a family to consider. I have great attendance and would never call in unless it was truly justified, but the occurrences make it very stressful. 
There are several policies that don't contribute to a positive working environment - at least in my department - and that makes the job hard to appreciate. While I have a good direct supervisor, it's luck of the draw whose team you get placed on and they're not all as great as my supervisor. 
Lastly, moving up to a new position is highly competitive. Several in my department have tried to apply for promotions or even just to a different position and they're always beat out by someone else.

job_title: Security Officer in Minneapolis, MN
pros:
The leadership in my department genuinely cares about us. They work hard to give us the best training and tools available. They are excellent at hiring qualified individuals who make our culture a pleasant one.

Benefits are excellent. I pay $10 for a doctor visit within my network.

Allina matches retirement contributions to a certain amount.

The people I work with make my work enjoyable.
cons:
The schedule is difficult, being staffed 24/7 means everyone works some weekends, or at least every other weekend.

The pay is not truly competitive. They only compare themselves to other not-for-profit hospitals of similar size which is a very small pool of competition. Many hospitals pay significantly better, but they insist that those hospitals don't count because they belong to a slightly different subcategory that somehow disqualifies them as competition in the job market.

The way they give raises is common throughout many large organizations, however it is still unfair. Once you have accepted a specific wage, you are locked in at that wage and can receive no more than a set percentage, for someone who exceeds expectations usually only about 3-4%. It is my understanding that the percentage is not decided by the direct supervisor or even the regional manager, who may only suggest an amount for approval. So the raises just barely keep ahead of inflation and the cost of living.
